Brownmiller speaks out on rape
By ROBBY RIGGS
Susan Brownmiller, author of
Against Our Will, spoke on the
legal history of rape for the M.
Carey Thomas Women's Center
last Wednesday night at Shriver
Hall.
The depth of her reflections
and research was evident as she
probed the effect rape statutes
and their psychological
implications have had on Western
culture. Her basic theme was
"the cultural acceptance of the
threat of the use of force by men
against women is a conscious
instrument by which men keep
women in fear."
She compared the
phenomenon of rape to that of
the lynching of blacks in the
South. Rapists, to Brownmiller,
are the front-line guerrillas in the
battle by men to keep women in
an inferior position.
Brownmiller traced the history
of rape, pointing out that it
occurs in no other animals except
humans. She noted that rape was
not considered a crime in
antiquity, and that in the Bible it
was even encouraged under
certain circumstances.
Rape was treated as theft, and
virgin women were considered

goods, until the thirteenth
century
, according to
Brownmiller. Men who raped
were thus able, and indeed were
obliged, to redeem themselves by
reimbursing the victim's family
and marrying the victim.
After a time, lowborn knights
began to exploit these rules by
stealing noble women for wives,
so Edward I of England
introduced the first modern
criminal laws about rape,
including the concept of
statutory rape.
Brownmiller derided several
Freudian notions concerning rape
which have arisen during the
twentieth century. The ideas that
women fantasize about rape and
that they are inherently
masochistic, while untrue, have
been "absolutely accepted" by
lawmakers, she stated.
She also denounced the
"glorification" of rape which has
made "cultural heroes" of Jack
the Ripper, the Boston Strangler,
and Eldridge Cleaver. "In the last
few years, there has been a
multitude of luscious rape scenes
in movies. If there had been
lynchings of blacks instead, it
absolutely would not have been
tolerated."

Thus, Brownmiller had the
courage to attack some of the
liberal ideas with which feminism
is often associated. She attacked
the white liberals who
acknowledged Cleaver's
"insurrectionary, revolutionary
right of rape." And her call for
an end to the institutions of
prostitution and pornography
came at the expense of civil
libertarians.
Labeling smut "sheer
anti-female propaganda," she
vowed, "I'm not afraid to use the
word censorship. I'm ready to
attack all of these civil
libertarians." Even more
imperative is the end of
prostitution. she maintained. "If
men grow up thinking that sex is
a service that can be purchased,
then they will reason that
whatever can be bought can also
be taken." .
Michael J. Cushing, a
self-proclaimed civil libertarian,
disagreed on thiq poira."If men
aren't allowed to pay to have sex,
then they'll have to resort to
rape." he claimed."Ending
prostitution would only make
the problem worse; besides, who
can say what is right or wrong for
a person to do with her body?"

As WJHU enters a new era, controversy simmers
By ROBBY RIGGS
For as long as any student now
at Homewood can remember, a
gaunt, haggard man named Bill
Gross has roamed the basement
of the dormitories. He was apt to
be spotted at any hour of the
day, on any day of the .week,
often with his hair uncombed, his
face unshaven, his clothes
wrinkled and dirty, and his arm
wrapped in a soiled brown sling.
Seven years ago, this man of
bizarre aspect became chief
engineer of radio station WJHU.
Since then, he has become
known as one of the strangest
figures ever associated with the
University. Dean of Students
Jakie Hall has called Gross "a
mystifying enigma."
This spring, newcomers to
WJHU have apparently succeeded
in deposing Gross. Newcomers,
that is, only in relation to Gross,
Who has been an institution at
the station. These students have
Painted a picture of him as a
domineering, power-loving man
who monopolized the operation
of the station.
A second, and completely
contrasting picture comes from
the recent faculty advisor of the
station , Dr. J.M. Minkowski.
Minkowski believes that Gross
was a dedicated, tireless worker
who built WJHU into a first-class
Operation. Since Gross dropped
completely out of sight two
months ago, Minkowski is the
only man on campus who can
reply to Gross's detractors.
Here are some of the mysteries
concerning Gross, and
Minkowski's statements with
regard to them.
--What was Gross's status in
the Hopkins community? Was he
paid to be chief engineer of
WJHU? If not, where did he earn
his livelihood?
One rumor which was
circulated freely among Gross's
former colleagues at WJHU is
that Gross repaired electrical
equipment, and that he is
currently being sued by one of
his former clients, which is why
he is now incommunicado. Gross
also left a considerable number
of miscellaneous auto parts in the
control room when he dropped
out of sight.

Minkowski: 'Bill Gross was an
undergraduate in the Electrical
Engineering department at
Hopkins, but he left without
graduating. He returned seven
years ago to become chief
engineer of WJHU. At the time,
he enrolled in several courses
here, and there was no
requirement in the WJHU
constitution that the officials of
the station be undergraduate
students.
'The radio station was very
small at that time. It had
broadcast only 6 hours daily.
Under Bill, it operated for as long
as there were people to run it,
sometimes 24 hours daily. Bill
put in very long hours, and he
was not paid at all. No one
could have been hired to do the
job that Bill did....
'Bill's family is not exactly
destitute. Aside from that, I
don't know where he got money
from.'
--WJHU operates under a large
handicap as an unlicensed AM
station. Eight attempts have been
made to convert the station to
FM, but none have ever been
successful. It has been asserted
that Gross sabotaged efforts to
make the change, in order to
avoid losing his commanding
position within WJHU. Similarly,
students have argued that he
withheld technical information
which would have enabled
students to run the station
without him.
Said Minkowski: 'The
attempts to convert to FM failed
for financial reasons. It is a long
process just to apply to the FCC,
and the FCC treats each
application as a competitive bid.'
He displayed an estimate for
conversion made in the 1960's
which put the cost at $75,000.
The station has also received
letters from schools which have
initiated FM broadcasting
ennumerating their headaches,
financial and otherwise.
'Bill has an immense
knowledge of the technology of
small radio stations, even
professional ones,' continued
Minkowski. 'The equipment here
is old, and it takes quite an
ability to run it. I think anyone
else who tries to run the station

will have problems. Probably the
best thing he could do would be
to contact Bill Gross.'
--What about Gross's health?
He has been wearing a sling on
his left arm for as long as anyone
can remember: There have been
rumors that his condition has
recently deteriorated, and that
death may even threaten him
since he staunchly refuses to have
his arm amputated.
According to Minkowski,
'Four or five years ago, an engine
fell on his arm. Since then, it has
been a chronic problem for Bill.
He has osteomyelitis, an
infection of the bone marrow,
which must be constantly
chntained.
'Bill refuses to have his arm
amputated because he is a superb
pianist. Instead, he has had a lot
of medical care, and a lot of
medical expenses to pay. His
condition is very serious,
although no basic difference in
his health has come about
recently.'

Back in the good old days...
operation was discontinued as of
February 10, according to a
letter from Minkowski to the
FCC. Several people now
connected with WJHU have
suggested that Gross may have
intentionally stepped up the

Minkowski called this

refuse to understand is that he is

'Bill did a complete field study

Bill is responsible. Bill had a good

--It seems probable that the
students who deposed Gross did
so largely because of a
personality conflict, and a
resultant power struggle . Jud
French would like to have Gross

to even communicate with the
station management.
Minkowski claimed that, 'The
young people didn't like the
discipline Bill imposed, especially
the tight control he exercised
over the record library. It is one
of the best record libraries on the
East Coast, with over 16,000
records worth over $100,000,
and some are irreplaceable. It was
built up by Bill's efforts, and
without discipline, it would
deteriorate.
The "young people" are
unhappy right now because the
possessor of the key to the
record library has not given it to
them. According to Minkowski,
'I have informed Dr. (George)
Benton that I will have it given to
him when he requests it, that is,
when he feels that the station has
responsible management."
Minkowski, however, does not
possess the key.

Gross did not actively attempt
to gain reelection as chief
engineer. He never considered the
elections legal, although the SAC
sanctioned them, and did not
even deign to show up. In fact,
he has not been seen at all on
campus lately, which makes it
seem probable that his health is
worse than Minkowski knew or
would admit. No one can even
get in touch with Gross. `You
don't get in touch with Gross; he
gets in touch with you," said
Larry Kenney, former record
librarian at WJHU and a close
associate of Gross's.
The newly elected managing
board of WJHU issued the
following statement in response
to the comments of Dr.
Minkowski:
In all its contacts with the
administration, the current
managing board of WJHU has
been urged to place ipolitics and
previous problems behind it and
concentrate all its efforts in two
very vital areas: (1) solidifying
the AM radio operations at Johns
Hopkins; and (2) developing a
concrete and final proposal for
conversion to FM stereo
broadcasting during the coming
year. The board and staff are
now working diligently on these
positive actions and have made
very good headway in only a few
short weeks. The board sees no
need to continue useless debate,
or to belabor past issues, of no
relevance to the station's present
or future.
Station Manager Don Osborne,
French, and the rest are
convinced that they can maintain
and even improve the station
operation, even if it means being
without Bill Gross. But in the
past, it has always been the
students who moved on, and
Gross who stayed, and that will
be hard to change. It is difficult
to conclude that Bill Gross, the
man who has made WJHU his
life, will not find his way back
into power again, if he survives to
have a chance.

I voted for zero budget
By WAYNE ABERNATHY
I am frequently told by my
compatriots on the SAC
Executive Committee that I
shouldn't try to represent their
views to others. In the same
spirit, then, I would appreciate it
if others on the Committee
would not try to represent my
views, especially when such
representation becomes
misrepresentation. The case in
point is with regard to the
budgeting of the News-Letter.
Let me be explicit in the
beginning: I voted in favor of
giving the News-Letter a zero
SAC budget figure for 1976-77.
My reasons for doing so,
however, are somewhat different
from those of other members on
the Committee, at least different
from what Ron Bialek has
expressed those views to be.
I am sure that no one is
unaware that there have been
problems this year with regard to
the News-Letter. No one,
including the editors I'm sure, is
completely satisfied with the
News-Letter. At the same time,
most students would agree that a
student-run Hopkins newspaper
is desirable, perhaps even
necessary. I see mainly three
problems that have been voiced,
each of differing importance.
One of these problems is not,
however, the question of salaries.
That problem was dealt with and,
I thought, concluded last year. I
am fairly certain that particular
salaries are necessary, and the
only questionable area may be in
the size of the salaries, and that
issue has not been raised in this
year's budgeting.
What has been most frequently
voiced as a problem concerns the
content and editorial policy of
the paper. It has been suggested
that not enough news about
Johns Hopkins, the Homewood
campus in particular, has been
printed. Coupled with this
complaint is that the News-Letter
has failed to give adequate
coverage to student government
and to student organizations in
general. This complaint became
particularly noticeable around
the time of Student Council
elections when many students
felt that they didn't know
enough about the candidates or
student government to make an
intelligent decision. The Friday
features issue of the News-Letter
has particularly (but . not
exclusively) come under attack,
many urging that the material
printed is rubbish (verbage,
useless) or at least inappropriate.
Regardless of the merits of the
arguments, the complaints have
been made and not by a few.
A second problem that has not
been so widely voiced, but which
is in my view equally important,
is that is has been alleged that the
staff of the News-Letter has been
abused by its management, or at
the very least that the working
atmosphere at the Gatehouse has
been less than desirable.
Importantly, this is an item that
has been raised from within the
News-Letter, by both present and
former staff members, both on
the masthead and off of it. The
SAC Executive Committee spent
much of the Fall semester (to be
sure, probably too much of it)

dealing with such a problem. The
News-Letter freely admits that it
is having difficulty in obtaining
and holding on to sufficient
numbers of staff members. In
fact, a member of the N-L
production team told me that the
paper may be forced to go to
only one issue a week due to not
having enough people working on
it. The editors suggest that this is
due to the amount of work and
dedication required. This may or
may not be true, but the point is
that there are complaints coming
from staff members to the
contrary.
The third problem is less
significant, but a problem just
the same. Many campus
organizations claim that
News-Letter ad rates for campus
organizations are too high, and
that the service that they receive
is inadequate. This inadequacy of
service includes complaints that
layout is poor, that there are too
many added costs, requirements
are too complicated, and that
working with N-L people to get
an ad printed is anything but
pleasant. Indeed, it is suggested
that News-Letter ad service is
typical of any organization that
has a monopoly in its area; i.e. if
you don't like the service, where
else are you to go?
All of these problems have
at one time or another, in some
form or another, come before the
SAC Executive Committee. The
powers and function of the SAC
are summed up as the promotion: and
regulation of student activities on
the Homewood campus. I would
agree that, at least for the time
that I'm aware of its activities,
the SAC has done too little
promotion and possibly too
much regulation, but I think that
this is more reflective of what the
Chairman has steered toward the
Commission and its Executive
Committee than it is of the
potential of the organization.
Regulation need not be the nasty
thing that it sounds like, and it
has been my intention that it not
be. If it has, I think that this was
more the result of execution than
of a desired policy. In fact, only
four organizations this past year
have had to suffer any kind of
regulation, and in at least one of
these instances I don't think that
you will find any complaints(ask
the people over at WJHU) other
than that the Executive
Committee was not involved
enough. The power of regulation
itself that the SAC possesses is
seeing
circumscribed to
that organizations operate
roughly within their budgets, and
ensuring that organizations
operate according to how they
were constitutionally chartered.
The first role emanates from the
responsibility that the SAC has
to member organizations in the
just distribution and use of
limited student activities funds,
in ensuring that no organization
misuses funds that could
otherwise have been used by
another SAC member group. The
second role comes from the
responsibility that the SAC has
to the individual students making
up the membership of the SAC
groups, in ensuring that
individuals are treated fairly
within, and have access to, each

group as outlined in its own
particular constitution.
What all of this means to me is
that it is incumbent upon the
SAC, and its Executive
Committee, to at least give ear
when it receives complaints that
an organization is violating one
of the above and to take the
necessary action if the complaint
is justified. As I have shown,
there have been complaints in at
least three areas with regard to
the News-Letter, and it has been
the duty of the SAC Executive
Committee to deal with them.
Unfortunately, the SAC has
been asked too frequently to deal
with complaints concerning the
News-Letter. It has been dealing
with these problems,some of them
frequent problems, that
produced the present budgetary
recommendation by the SAC
Executive Committee to the
body of the whole SAC. Not at
all as a punitive measure, I see
the decision as a long term
solution that is beneficial for the
News- Letter, student
government, and the students
alike. My vote on the
News-Letter appropriation was
tied to another vote in the
1976-77 SAC budget: the
allocation of funds for the
creation of a second student
publication here at Homewood. I
could not have voted one
without the other.
The News-Letter is a weird
creature among SAC groups for a
number of reasons. First of all,
the SAC Exedutive Committee
has singularly had difficulties in
the carrying out of its
responsibilities with regard to the
News-Letter. Each time that the
Committee has tried-to deal with
the paper the N-L people have
jumped up on the soap-box and
cried censorship. This is a
particularly hard cry to combat,
whether or not it is justified,
because of the sensitivity of most
people to the issue. Even
suggestions that the News-Letter
pay more attention to the
Homewood campus and less to
Charles Village were met with
cries of violation of freedom of
the press. The present
controversy serves as another
example of this, even though
absolutely no mention was made
about editorial policy and format
in the budget notification sent to
the News-Letter, and had such a
recommendation been made in
the Executive Committee I
would have strongly fought it.
The cries, though unjustified, are
rather understandable, for
budgeting and appropriations is a
very sensitive time for SAC
groups. What is not sufficiently
understood is that a zero budget
appropriation (self-sufficient)
News-Letter is probably the best
situation for improved relations
between it and the SAC. The
News-Letter no longer has to fear
SAC control through the power
of the purse-strings (the SAC's
most potent, but rarely used,
weapon), and the SAC no longer
has to suffer accusations of using
this power for censorship each
time that it touches on an issue
concerning the paper.

By WES PARDUE
It was a bright, sunny Friday.
That alone was significant.
Usually, the weekdays were
beautiful while each weekend
promised to be a deluge. This
week had been different. This
week we swam to class on
Tuesday and Wednesday. Friday
was clear. Portentious, I thought.
• I walked back from the
student union having once again
gazed into an empty mailbox. I
knew that in a week it would fill
and I would join the smug group
opening boxes and pulling out
letters—my birthday was near.
Twenty years. And what to show
for it? As a child, I had thought
that by now I would surely be a
millionaire, have world fame,
and, most of all, have
tremendous knowledge.
Instead—well, I was still- in
school, known only to myself,
and frequently had difficulty
deciding whether to wear brown
or blue socks with my attire.
Things had changed less than

expected.
Walking between the library
and Foster Hall I came upon a
group of first graders. A woman
of about thirty was instructing
them - that there were classes
going on and it was imperative
that they be quiet. The boys and
girls were holding hands—boys
with boys and girls with girls. In
a few years you'll be embarrassed
to do that, I thought. Too bad. It
would probably help if we all
touched a bit more.
Apparition
The teacher was explaining
about the natural science exhibit
they were about to see in Foster
Hall. As I was listening to her
fount of misinformation I was
startled to see a slight boy with
deep set brown eyes looking at
me. I don't know if he saw his
future self by looking at me, but
I certainly saw myself in him. It
was an apparition from my past,
even to the detail of standing
precariously balanced on the left
foot, the right raised and placed

against the left knee, with hands
on hips. He had his head cocked
to the left and as we looked at
each other I knew I must pass on
some jewel, some guiding light,
to lead him on. What had I
learned in twenty years? As I
racked my brain, he squinted
myopically and I realized that
soon he—I—would be getting
glasses.
Four eyes. Dropped footballs.
Missed baskets.
I stepped forward and gave
him twenty years of regrets. The
class was now shuffling noisily
toward the museum. I cleared my
throat. "Eat your carrots." I
adjusted my glasses to punctuate.
He frowned, disgusted. Surely he
would have more to reveal after
twenty years. He turned away,
took two steps, and tripped over
a large oak root. I rolled my eyes,
took two steps, and bumped into
a co-ed. I heard him laugh, and
saw him run to catch up with the
rest of the class. The lesson was
taught.

By ROBBY RIGGS
Susan Brownmiller, author of
Against Our Will, spoke on the
legal history of rape for the M.
Carey Thomas Women's Center
last Wednesday night at Shriver
Hall.
The depth of her reflections
and research was evident as she
probed the effect rape statutes
and their psychological
implications have had on Western
culture. Her basic theme was
"the cultural acceptance of the
threat of the use of force by men
against women is a conscious
instrument by which men keep
women in fear."
She compared the
phenomenon of rape to that of
the lynching of blacks in the
South. Rapists, to Brownmiller,
are the front-line guerrillas in the
battle by men to keep women in
an inferior position.
Brownmiller traced the history
of rape, pointing out that it
occurs in no other animals except
humans. She noted that rape was
not considered a crime in
antiquity, and that in the Bible it
was even encouraged under
certain circumstances.
Rape was treated as theft, and
virgin women were considered

goods, until the thirteenth
century
, according to
Brownmiller. Men who raped
were thus able, and indeed were
obliged, to redeem themselves by
reimbursing the victim's family
and marrying the victim.
After a time, lowborn knights
began to exploit these rules by
stealing noble women for wives,
so Edward I of England
introduced the first modern
criminal laws about rape,
including the concept of
statutory rape.
Brownmiller derided several
Freudian notions concerning rape
which have arisen during the
twentieth century. The ideas that
women fantasize about rape and
that they are inherently
masochistic, while untrue, have
been "absolutely accepted" by
lawmakers, she stated.
She also denounced the
"glorification" of rape which has
made "cultural heroes" of Jack
the Ripper, the Boston Strangler,
and Eldridge Cleaver. "In the last
few years, there has been a
multitude of luscious rape scenes
in movies. If there had been
lynchings of blacks instead, it
absolutely would not have been
tolerated."

Thus, Brownmiller had the
courage to attack some of the
liberal ideas with which feminism
is often associated. She attacked
the white liberals who
acknowledged Cleaver's
"insurrectionary, revolutionary
right of rape." And her call for
an end to the institutions of
prostitution and pornography

libertarians.
Labeling smut "sheer
anti-female propaganda," she
vowed, "I'm not afraid to use the
word censorship. I'm ready to
attack all of these civil
libertarians." Even more
imperative is the end of
prostitution. she maintained. "If
men grow up thinking that sex is
a service that can be purchased,
then they will reason that
whatever can be bought can also
be taken." .

For as long as any student now

I voted for zero budget
By WAYNE ABERNATHY
I am frequently told by my
compatriots on the SAC
Executive Committee that I
shouldn't try to represent their
views to others. In the same
spirit, then, I would appreciate it
if others on the Committee
would not try to represent my
views, especially when such
representation becomes
misrepresentation. The case in
point is with regard to the
budgeting of the News-Letter.
Let me be explicit in the
beginning: I voted in favor of
giving the News-Letter a zero
SAC budget figure for 1976-77.
My reasons for doing so,
however, are somewhat different
from those of other members on
the Committee, at least different
from what Ron Bialek has
expressed those views to be.
I am sure that no one is
unaware that there have been
problems this year with regard to
the News-Letter. No one,
including the editors I'm sure, is
completely satisfied with the
News-Letter. At the same time,
most students would agree that a
student-run Hopkins newspaper
is desirable, perhaps even
necessary. I see mainly three
problems that have been voiced,
each of differing importance.
One of these problems is not,
however, the question of salaries.
That problem was dealt with and,
I thought, concluded last year. I
am fairly certain that particular
salaries are necessary, and the
only questionable area may be in
the size of the salaries, and that
issue has not been raised in this
year's budgeting.
What has been most frequently
voiced as a problem concerns the
content and editorial policy of
the paper. It has been suggested
that not enough news about
Johns Hopkins, the Homewood
campus in particular, has been
printed. Coupled with this
complaint is that the News-Letter
has failed to give adequate
coverage to student government
and to student organizations in
general. This complaint became
particularly noticeable around
the time of Student Council
elections when many students
felt that they didn't know
enough about the candidates or
student government to make an
intelligent decision. The Friday
features issue of the News-Letter
has particularly (but . not
exclusively) come under attack,
many urging that the material
printed is rubbish (verbage,
useless) or at least inappropriate.
Regardless of the merits of the
arguments, the complaints have
been made and not by a few.
A second problem that has not
been so widely voiced, but which
is in my view equally important,
is that is has been alleged that the
staff of the News-Letter has been
abused by its management, or at
the very least that the working
atmosphere at the Gatehouse has
been less than desirable.
Importantly, this is an item that
has been raised from within the
News-Letter, by both present and
former staff members, both on
the masthead and off of it. The
SAC Executive Committee spent
much of the Fall semester (to be
sure, probably too much of it)

dealing with such a problem. The
News-Letter freely admits that it
is having difficulty in obtaining
and holding on to sufficient
numbers of staff members. In
fact, a member of the N-L
production team told me that the
paper may be forced to go to
only one issue a week due to not
having enough people working on
it. The editors suggest that this is
due to the amount of work and
dedication required. This may or
may not be true, but the point is
that there are complaints coming
from staff members to the
contrary.
The third problem is less
significant, but a problem just
the same. Many campus
organizations claim that
News-Letter ad rates for campus
organizations are too high, and
that the service that they receive
is inadequate. This inadequacy of
service includes complaints that
layout is poor, that there are too
many added costs, requirements
are too complicated, and that
working with N-L people to get
an ad printed is anything but
pleasant. Indeed, it is suggested
that News-Letter ad service is
typical of any organization that
has a monopoly in its area; i.e. if
you don't like the service, where
else are you to go?
All of these problems have
at one time or another, in some
form or another, come before the
SAC Executive Committee. The
powers and function of the SAC
are summed up as the promotion: and
regulation of student activities on
the Homewood campus. I would
agree that, at least for the time
that I'm aware of its activities,
the SAC has done too little
promotion and possibly too
much regulation, but I think that
this is more reflective of what the
Chairman has steered toward the
Commission and its Executive
Committee than it is of the
potential of the organization.
Regulation need not be the nasty
thing that it sounds like, and it
has been my intention that it not
be. If it has, I think that this was
more the result of execution than
of a desired policy. In fact, only
four organizations this past year
have had to suffer any kind of
regulation, and in at least one of
these instances I don't think that
you will find any complaints(ask
the people over at WJHU) other
than that the Executive
Committee was not involved
enough. The power of regulation
itself that the SAC possesses is
seeing
circumscribed to
that organizations operate
roughly within their budgets, and
ensuring that organizations
operate according to how they
were constitutionally chartered.
The first role emanates from the
responsibility that the SAC has
to member organizations in the
just distribution and use of
limited student activities funds,
in ensuring that no organization
misuses funds that could
otherwise have been used by
another SAC member group. The
second role comes from the
responsibility that the SAC has
to the individual students making
up the membership of the SAC
groups, in ensuring that
individuals are treated fairly
within, and have access to, each

group as outlined in its own
particular constitution.
What all of this means to me is
that it is incumbent upon the
SAC, and its Executive
Committee, to at least give ear
when it receives complaints that
an organization is violating one
of the above and to take the
necessary action if the complaint
is justified. As I have shown,
there have been complaints in at
least three areas with regard to
the News-Letter, and it has been
the duty of the SAC Executive
Committee to deal with them.
Unfortunately, the SAC has
been asked too frequently to deal
with complaints concerning the
News-Letter. It has been dealing
with these problems,some of them
frequent problems, that
produced the present budgetary
recommendation by the SAC
Executive Committee to the
body of the whole SAC. Not at
all as a punitive measure, I see
the decision as a long term
solution that is beneficial for the
News- Letter, student
government, and the students
alike. My vote on the
News-Letter appropriation was
tied to another vote in the
1976-77 SAC budget: the
allocation of funds for the
creation of a second student
publication here at Homewood. I
could not have voted one
without the other.
The News-Letter is a weird
creature among SAC groups for a
number of reasons. First of all,
the SAC Exedutive Committee
has singularly had difficulties in
the carrying out of its
responsibilities with regard to the
News-Letter. Each time that the
Committee has tried-to deal with
the paper the N-L people have
jumped up on the soap-box and
cried censorship. This is a
particularly hard cry to combat,
whether or not it is justified,
because of the sensitivity of most
people to the issue. Even
suggestions that the News-Letter
pay more attention to the
Homewood campus and less to
Charles Village were met with
cries of violation of freedom of
the press. The present
controversy serves as another
example of this, even though
absolutely no mention was made
about editorial policy and format
in the budget notification sent to
the News-Letter, and had such a
recommendation been made in
the Executive Committee I
would have strongly fought it.
The cries, though unjustified, are
rather understandable, for
budgeting and appropriations is a
very sensitive time for SAC
groups. What is not sufficiently
understood is that a zero budget
appropriation (self-sufficient)
News-Letter is probably the best
situation for improved relations
between it and the SAC. The
News-Letter no longer has to fear
SAC control through the power
of the purse-strings (the SAC's
most potent, but rarely used,
weapon), and the SAC no longer
has to suffer accusations of using
this power for censorship each
time that it touches on an issue
concerning the paper.

By WES PARDUE
It was a bright, sunny Friday.
That alone was significant.
Usually, the weekdays were
beautiful while each weekend
promised to be a deluge. This
week had been different. This
week we swam to class on
Tuesday and Wednesday. Friday
was clear. Portentious, I thought.
• I walked back from the
student union having once again
gazed into an empty mailbox. I
knew that in a week it would fill
and I would join the smug group
opening boxes and pulling out
letters—my birthday was near.
Twenty years. And what to show
for it? As a child, I had thought
that by now I would surely be a
millionaire, have world fame,
and, most of all, have
tremendous knowledge.
Instead—well, I was still- in
school, known only to myself,
and frequently had difficulty
deciding whether to wear brown
or blue socks with my attire.
Things had changed less than

expected.
Walking between the library
and Foster Hall I came upon a
group of first graders. A woman
of about thirty was instructing
them - that there were classes
going on and it was imperative
that they be quiet. The boys and
girls were holding hands—boys
with boys and girls with girls. In
a few years you'll be embarrassed
to do that, I thought. Too bad. It
would probably help if we all
touched a bit more.
Apparition
The teacher was explaining
about the natural science exhibit
they were about to see in Foster
Hall. As I was listening to her
fount of misinformation I was
startled to see a slight boy with
deep set brown eyes looking at
me. I don't know if he saw his
future self by looking at me, but
I certainly saw myself in him. It
was an apparition from my past,
even to the detail of standing
precariously balanced on the left
foot, the right raised and placed

against the left knee, with hands
on hips. He had his head cocked
to the left and as we looked at
each other I knew I must pass on
some jewel, some guiding light,
to lead him on. What had I
learned in twenty years? As I
racked my brain, he squinted
myopically and I realized that
soon he—I—would be getting
glasses.
Four eyes. Dropped footballs.
Missed baskets.
I stepped forward and gave
him twenty years of regrets. The
class was now shuffling noisily
toward the museum. I cleared my
throat. "Eat your carrots." I
adjusted my glasses to punctuate.
He frowned, disgusted. Surely he
would have more to reveal after
twenty years. He turned away,
took two steps, and tripped over
a large oak root. I rolled my eyes,
took two steps, and bumped into
a co-ed. I heard him laugh, and
saw him run to catch up with the
rest of the class. The lesson was
taught.
